thm pilem1(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈(ℝ+ ⋂(`' sin " { 0 }))↔(c0 ∈ ℝ+ ∧(sin ` c0)= 0))
} = {
  bitri(c0 ∈(ℝ+ ⋂(`' sin " { 0 })), (c0 ∈ ℝ+ ∧(sin ` c0)= 0), (c0 ∈ ℝ+ ∧ c0 ∈(`' sin " { 0 })))
  elin(c0, crp, (`' sin " { 0 }))
  pm5.32i(c0 ∈ ℝ+, c0 ∈(`' sin " { 0 }), (sin ` c0)= 0)
  syl6rbbr(c0 ∈ ℝ+, c0 ∈(`' sin " { 0 }), (sin ` c0)= 0, (c0 ∈ ℂ ∧(sin ` c0)= 0))
  biantrurd(c0 ∈ ℝ+, (sin ` c0)= 0, c0 ∈ ℂ)
  rpcn(c0)
  mp2b((c0 ∈(`' sin " { 0 })↔(c0 ∈ ℂ ∧(sin ` c0)= 0)), (sin : ℂ → ℂ), sin[Fn]ℂ)
  sinf()
  ffn(csin, cc, cc)
  fniniseg(csin, cc, c0, nat0)

  oveq12i(cfv(ccos, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)), caddc, co(ci, cmul, cfv(csin, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2))), nat0, ci)
  coshalfpi()

  sylan9eqr(co(cfv(ce, c0), cmul, cfv(ce, co(co(ci, cmul, co(nat2, cmul, cpi)), cmul, c1))), cfv(ce, c0), co(cfv(ce, c0), cmul, nat1), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cz))

thm sinmpi(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ ℂ →(sin `(c0[-]π))= -u((sin ` c0)))
} = {
  eqtrd((sin `(c0[-]π)), -u((sin ` c0)), (((sin ` c0)[×](cos ` π))[-]((cos ` c0)[×](sin ` π))), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  mpan2(c0 ∈ ℂ, (sin `(c0[-]π))=(((sin ` c0)[×](cos ` π))[-]((cos ` c0)[×](sin ` π))), π ∈ ℂ)
  picn()
  sinsub(c0, cpi)
  eqtrd((((sin ` c0)[×](cos ` π))[-]((cos ` c0)[×](sin ` π))), -u((sin ` c0)), (-u((sin ` c0))[-]0), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  oveq12d(((sin ` c0)[×](cos ` π)), cmin, ((cos ` c0)[×](sin ` π)), -u((sin ` c0)), nat0, c0 ∈ ℂ)
  syl5eq(((sin ` c0)[×](cos ` π)), -u((sin ` c0)), ((sin ` c0)[×]-u(1)), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  oveq2i((sin ` c0), cmul, (cos ` π), -u(1))
  cospi()
  syl(c0 ∈ ℂ, ((sin ` c0)[×]-u(1))= -u((sin ` c0)), (sin ` c0)∈ ℂ)
  eqtrd(((sin ` c0)[×]-u(1)), -u((sin ` c0)), (-u(1)[×](sin ` c0)), (sin ` c0)∈ ℂ)
  mpan2((sin ` c0)∈ ℂ, ((sin ` c0)[×]-u(1))=(-u(1)[×](sin ` c0)), -u(1)∈ ℂ)
  neg1cn()
  mulcom((sin ` c0), -u(1))
  mulm1((sin ` c0))
  syl5eq(((cos ` c0)[×](sin ` π)), nat0, ((cos ` c0)[×]0), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  oveq2i((cos ` c0), cmul, (sin ` π), nat0)
  sinpi()
  mul01d((cos ` c0), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  coscl(c0)
  subid1d(-u((sin ` c0)), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  negcld((sin ` c0), c0 ∈ ℂ)
  sincl(c0)
}

blocks.name: ptolemy
blocks.content: Ptolemy's Theorem. This theorem is named after the Greek astronomer and mathematician Ptolemy (Claudius Ptolemaeus). This particular version is expressed using the sine function. It is proved by expanding all the multiplication of sines to a product of cosines of differences using ~ sinmul , then using algebraic simplification to show that both sides are equal. This formalization is based on the proof in "Trigonometry" by Gelfand and Saul. This is Metamath 100 proof #95. (Contributed by David A. Wheeler, 31-May-2015.)

blocks.name: tanabsge
blocks.content: The tangent function is greater than or equal to its argument in absolute value. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 25-Feb-2015.)

  coshalfpim(co(c0, cmul, co(cpi, cdiv, nat2)))

blocks.name: pige3
blocks.content: ` _pi ` is greater than or equal to 3. This proof is based on the geometric observation that a hexagon of unit side length has perimeter 6, which is less than the unit-radius circumcircle, of perimeter ` 2 _pi ` . We translate this to algebra by looking at the function ` _e ^ ( _i x ) ` as ` x ` goes from ` 0 ` to ` _pi / 3 ` ; it moves at unit speed and travels distance ` 1 ` , hence ` 1 <_ _pi / 3 ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 21-May-2016.)

  mpan(wcel(c0, cz), wceq(cfv(cabs, cfv(csin, co(nat0, caddc, co(c0, cmul, cpi)))), cfv(cabs, cfv(csin, nat0))), wcel(nat0, cc))
  0cn()

thm sinkpi(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ ℤ →(sin `(c0[×]π))= 0)
} = {
  eqtr3d((sin `(c0[×]π)), nat0, (sin `(0[+](c0[×]π))), c0 ∈ ℤ)
  fveq2d(csin, (0[+](c0[×]π)), (c0[×]π), c0 ∈ ℤ)
  addid2d((c0[×]π), c0 ∈ ℤ)
  abs00d((sin `(0[+](c0[×]π))), c0 ∈ ℤ)
  sincld((0[+](c0[×]π)), c0 ∈ ℤ)
  sylancr(c0 ∈ ℤ, (0[+](c0[×]π))∈ ℂ, 0 ∈ ℂ, (c0[×]π)∈ ℂ)
  sylancl(c0 ∈ ℤ, (c0[×]π)∈ ℂ, c0 ∈ ℂ, π ∈ ℂ)
  zcn(c0)
  picn()
  mulcl(c0, cpi)
  addcl(nat0, (c0[×]π))
  syl6eq((abs `(sin `(0[+](c0[×]π)))), nat0, (abs `(sin ` 0)), c0 ∈ ℤ)
  mpan(c0 ∈ ℤ, (abs `(sin `(0[+](c0[×]π))))=(abs `(sin ` 0)), 0 ∈ ℂ)
  0cn()
  abssinper(nat0, c0)

  ex(wa(wcel(c0, co(nat0, cicc, cpi)), wcel(c1, co(nat0, cicc, cpi))), wbr(c1, clt, c0), wbr(cfv(ccos, c0), clt, cfv(ccos, c1)))

blocks.name: tanord1
blocks.content: The tangent function is strictly increasing on the nonnegative part of its principal domain. (Lemma for ~ tanord .) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 29-Jul-2014.) Revised to replace an OLD theorem. (Revised by Wolf Lammen, 20-Sep-2020.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: tanord
blocks.content: The tangent function is strictly increasing on its principal domain. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 4-Apr-2015.)

blocks.name: negpitopissre
blocks.content: The interval ` ( -u _pi (,] _pi ) ` is a subset of the reals. (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
